text:
Sport Opinion If you are tired of the idealistic way Pep Guardiola's Manchester City play, you are tired of football The Spaniard believes there is only one form of defence and that is to attack PLUS: Leicester, Neil Warnock and more Share Sport Opinion Guardiola couldn't get City to defy their instincts and try to increase the lead they took to Monaco (Photo: Getty) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Forget about the concession of another three goals, Pep Guardiola says Manchester City ’s problem was they didn’t attack enough in Monaco. 
He was right. 
The players’ instincts were clearly telling them, despite boss Guardiola ’s urgings to the contrary, that they had a two-goal advantage and to hold on to rather than to increase it. 
They were caught between two mindsets — a normal footballing one and Guardiola’s idealistic one. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Pep refuses to blame his defense after crashing out to Monaco Share this video STAN COLLYMORE: Why I'm enjoying seeing Guardiola tested at last with Man City 
Guardiola’s one is that there is, indeed, only one form of defence and that is to attack. 
And the more this Utopian vision is held up to criticism and even ridicule, the more entrenched he will become. 
Quite what chairman Khaldoon Al Mubarak and owner Sheikh Mansour will make of where that vision has taken their Blues this season is an interesting point. 
But if, either as a City supporter or not, you are already tired of the way Guardiola’s team plays, you are tired of football. poll loading As Man City manager, Pep Guardiola will win... 0+ VOTES SO FAR Neither LEICESTER'S HISTORY LESSEN 
It is time to move on and give Leicester 's players the praise they deserve for their progression to the last eight of the Champions League . 
There was always going to be a response after the withering criticism they received, but such has been their transformation since his sacking that you now know for sure they really were not having Claudio Ranieri . Leicester are transformed since sacking last season's hero Ranieri (Photo: Plumb Images/Leicester City/Getty) Read More Leicester boss defends Jamie Vardy after sent-off Samir Nasri's "cheat" jibe' 
Managers and players do fall out, but the single regrettable thing about what has unfolded at Leicester is that history might eventually downplay Ranieri’s role in one of the greatest club-football stories told. 
Right now, these players are sending out a message that says they won the title last season DESPITE Ranieri, not BECAUSE of him. 
That’s sad. Will Leicester reach the Champions League semis? 500+ VOTES SO FAR NO WARNOCK'S NOT-SO-WISECRACK 
Neil Warnock has always been one of the most underrated managers in the game and has always had a tendency to let himself down now and again. 
When he said recently he did not worry about the sack because he would always get another job, Cardiff boss Warnock was right. 
The context of his comments was Wigan’s dismissal of Warren Joyce just four months after he was recruited from Manchester United’s youth set-up. Cardiff boss Warnock will stay as popular as ever after his latest comments (Photo: Getty) 
“No disrespect but when Wigan appointed him, I was delighted,” said Warnock, whose Bluebirds were then battling with the Latics in the Championship's relegation scrap. 
An underrated manager, yes. 
But not hard to understand why some anagram-loving contemporaries know Neil Warnock as 'Colin'. STILL FAIRWAY TO GO FOR GOLF 
Rory McIlroy is speaking his mind a lot nowadays. And it is brilliant. 
He was not congratulating Muirfield on its decision to finally give up its men-only policy , but saying how it had been ‘obscene’ and that, when The Open returns there, he wouldn’t be having any cups of tea with the members, 20 per cent of whom still voted to keep women out. 
Good on him. 
Presumably and understandably, though, McIlroy - much younger then, and making his way - did not feel it appropriate to make any comment about Augusta’s refusal to allow women members which was still in force when he made his Masters debut in 2009. 
Not many golfers, if any, did. Golf has an even bigger 'ism' to deal with than the one highlighted at Muirfield (Photo: PA) 
Augusta relented in the summer of 2012 and gave the first female memberships to Condoleeza Rice and Darla Moore. 
Rice is the former Secretary of State and Moore is a billionaire financier. 
Muirfield finally following Augusta’s lead is clearly a welcome, if ridiculously overdue, step. 
But aspiring girl golfers from humble backgrounds should not be getting too excited. 
Sexism in golf clubs has always been an issue. Elitism has always been a bigger one. Like us on Facebook
